author: geekship
title: SOIL: OriginTrail / Ontochain (DKG)
description: A Decentralized Knowledge Graph is being developed by Origintrail, with integrations with Ethereum, Gnosis, Polygon, and recently Polkadot. Cardano should also be supported.

f6_assessments.q0: The proposal unclearly addresses the challenge. The reader understands the DKG is supporting other chains and Cardano could be added to this but their isn't an expression of what this means in regards to the challenge. It ticks the box of being cross-chain but doesn't dive any deeper than that.
f6_assessments.q1:
The proposer has a history in software development which is great to see. It's also great they showed honesty in regards to their little experience with EVM or DKG. The one issue of this honesty is it present a bit of a hole in the proposal in regards to potential for successful implementation. 

The risks section brings up two major issues in regards to whether it will be feasible or not on Cardano with IOGs EVM side chain and that Origintrail will then need to give it support. Unfortunately these big issues don't have strong mitigation strategies. It would have been great to seem more information on the Origintrail support process and how Cardano EVM side chain compatibility could be ensured. 

In the detailed budget section the proposer mentions using the money to hire someone or bribe Origintrail. This creates a lack of confidence in the potential for successful use of funds. 

Overall there isn't an exact plan beyond getting $5k and then using it to get someone else to implement OriginTrail on Cardano. The reader needs a much clearer plan to understand if this proposal will be successful or not.
f6_assessments.q2:
The proposed solution section is strongly lacking in information. I understand the proposer wants to implement DKG into Cardano but there isn't an expression of what this will do for Cardano. How will developers interact with it? How will the users of those developed solution benefit? A much longer multi-paragraph proposed solution section would have been great to get a better sense of what's to come.

The detailed plan section is also lacking in information. More potential issues are brought up around proposer working to outsource the project and a timeline is only given if proposer achieves external funding. It would have been great to see a set amount of deliverables along with their associated timeline

f6_assessments.q0:
Having a hard time accessing the impact of this proposal and how it address the challenge with a single sentences response to "describe the proposal solution" and "how it will address the challenge." Without more, lots more details about your solution, the community has no way to gauge the impact. 

Some questions to help you flush out the proposal:
How it will add value to the Cardano ecosystem? 
What specific ask, key metrics, solution ideas, or indication of success describe in the challenge brief is the proposal explicitly speaking to?
What types of objects do you plan to provide via the knowledge graph?
How will the community interface with with? Who is it for? Users? Developers?
f6_assessments.q1:
The proposal provides no detail about specifically how the 5K will be spent, or any milestone or deliverable. The author has not committed to executing the  proposal nor have the proposal provide any details about the team, experience, or qualification. 

Perhaps a better approach would have been finding a team excited about and refer them to catalyst. You make monies, and they get to write a stronger proposal that the community can better access it's feasibility.
f6_assessments.q2: The proposal provides no detail about plans to track and manage work internally nor about how the community will be able to follow along. Is a there a fork of an open source repo the community can follow? How will you report progress or roadblocks?

f6_assessments.q0:
OriginTrail is dubbed as “Google for Blockchain” and its purpose is to make real-world assets traceable on blockchain and this asset data searchable with their decentralized knowledge graph. I know quite a bit about this because I have been following their journey for about 1.5 years now as a small-scale investor, crowd loan participant and a non-technical fanboy.

This proposal is not a traditional proposal per se. Instead it is a bounty for anyone who is ready to implement the connection between Cardano and OriginTrail. These two are both important rails of the future and they should be connected. For that reason, I fully agree this should get done. Unfortunately the proposer has not made the proposal quite complete enough to be given five stars.
f6_assessments.q1:
OriginTrail Decentralized Knowledge Graph and their consensus layer are in fact two different entities, first a semantic chain and the second a multi-chain functioning on Ethereum, Polygon and now also as a Parachain on Polkadot. They also have two different tokens, TRAC and OTP. The former is an ERC-20 token and the latter is a governance token on Substrate (Polkadot). If I have understood correctly, going forward, all other chains (like Cardano) can connect with that parachain. Point being, perhaps the connection via the EVM sidechain is not even needed.

The proposer sees the importance of connecting Cardano with OriginTrail but doesn’t have time or capacity to do it on his own. Therefore, it is a clever solution to raise the topic and earmark $5,000 of ADA (treasury money) as a bounty for anyone who does have both the competence and bandwidth to get it done.
f6_assessments.q2:
Due to the unorthodox nature of this proposal, it is impossible to evaluate the auditability according to the same guidelines. 

Interested to claim the bounty? Vote and read more: https://docs.origintrail.io/

f6_assessments.q0:
While the general principle of bringing OriginTrail onto Cardano seems a solid one, this proposal is not clear or thought out about what the outcome of doing that would mean, and what impact that would have. 

While it does meet with the challenge goal to expand the ecosystem, it doesn't do it in a way that implies a clear why we should focus resources on this now.
f6_assessments.q1:
No.  The project is dependent on a principal who has other projects and employment who will need to hire (or bribe per the proposal) people to do the actual work.  There are few indicators of success in project planning here in terms of a clear plan, deliverables, timeline and why, and crucially who will do the actual work.

I surmise the idea is there, what the proposal didn't give me is belief this idea has been effectively planted and that it will germinate.
f6_assessments.q2:
As there isn't a clear plan presented, there is by definition little ability to evaluate success.

As the proposal didn't include a clear "why" for the project, we would be challenged to evaluate if it worked.

f6_assessments.q0:
From the perspective of someone who has led projects and teams that utilize graph databases since 2015, published articles, taught, and spoke at conferences, Cardano and other (e)UTxO blockchains are much better suited than account model blockchains.
Now that my bias in favor of everything graph is in the open, there are some weaknesses with the proposal.
The proposer offloads highlighting the value proposition by sharing links to OriginTrail. However, it does not become apparent what the impact may be.
Despite build breaks, 16 open pull requests, and 45 open issues, v6/develop branch of the network node of OriginTrail, ot-node, has not received an update in two months at the time of this review. The major question is how a DKG backend on Cardano would address the challenge questions - this proposal makes no attempt in answering the question. The claim that because Ethereum, Gnosis (never heard of them), and Polkadot (its support is actually still in development according to the linked website) are supported, Cardano needs to be supported as well is not explained.

Interoperability is easy to understand as falling in the realm of this challenge, but overall, I see serious issues in the proposal as it does not answer most of the questions related to impact sufficiently.
f6_assessments.q1:
The proposer himself will not work on the implementation of this proposal. Unless OriginTail has a working solution already and the timing works out that Martin “bribes” them just prior to the release announcement, I do not see how it is feasible to “hire someone” for $5k to complete this in October.
The provided references are useless as we do not know who would be hired to do the job. Even just from the perspective of a Plutus Pioneer from the first cohort and someone who works with Plutus regularly, I can assure you that you will not find someone who can lift this project sufficiently for $5k - not if you contract someone. People who really know graphs are few. This is not just a simple copy and paste Solidity type of gig either. If the proposer had the skills (his LinkedIn and website don’t indicate this) to do it himself and take a huge paycut, maybe that would be feasible. A third party dependency is also problematic. Looking for IO to have products production ready is a strategy that is almost guaranteed to fail. Many Catalyst proposers have been burned by taking communicated wishes and deadlines by C.H. as guarantees that the product is shipped by that date. As we know, that is often not the case.
But because this section is essentially a huge question mark and the proposer himself does not know if it’s feasible and lacks a detailed plan, I give this section the lowest rating.
f6_assessments.q2: It can be reasonably assumed that “open source contribution” would mean that the community could track progress of inputs on Github. Success means that Cardano would be officially added to the OriginTrail website. These scenarios, while cumbersome, are in theory trackable by the community. However, the proposal falls short in showing a detailed roadmap with milestones and a total lack of KPIs as it relates to challenge goals.

f6_assessments.q0:
By integrating Cardano in the Decentralized Knowledge Graph (DKG), Cardano would be able to work parallel to other popular blockchains in the solution such as Ethereum, Polygon and Polkadot. This exposes Cardano to a wider group of blockchain users and poses the possibility of on-boarding new members to the community. The intentions of this proposal directly increase interoperability and enhance the multi-chain future which Cardano strives to become a fundamental part of. The DKG would enable Cardano to coordinate and collaborate with other chains and build a strong and solid basis for further integration between Cardano and other blockchains in the future.
This proposal aligns very well with the campaign brief of the “Cross-chain collaboration” challenge as mentioned above. Therefore, it receives 5 points in terms of impact.
f6_assessments.q1: The feasibility of the proposal is rather poor, given the information provided in the proposal. The author claims to be busy with other proposals and they might be able to outsource the work for this, if it were to be funded. It lacks a detailed plan, milestones and clearly stated goals. No real timetable is provided and the proposal seems more like a draft than a finished proposal in its current state. It is recommended to add the above mentioned information in order for this proposal to achieve a higher score in the future. It is filled with too many if’s and maybe’s instead of a clear path to success. Therefore, it is hard to believe that the proposal will be successful, even if it were to be funded. A score of 1 point is given, but the author is encouraged to refine the proposal to the next fund.
f6_assessments.q2: Unfortunately the auditability is also poor in the proposal in its current state. In order for the community to audit the progress of the proposal we would need milestones, measurable KPIs and a clear definition of success. Furthermore the timeline is vague and there is no official channel where progress reports will be provided to the community. This should all be addressed in a refined version of this proposal in order to gain a great rating in the future. For now, it is not auditable and will receive a score of 1 point.

f6_assessments.q0:
This proposal seeks funding for the implementation of Decentralized Knowledge Graph (DKG) backend on Cardano. The  OriginTrail is a set of tools and protocols designed to bring semantics to Web3. 
The Origintrail, has integrations with Ethereum, Gnosis, Polygon, and recently Polkadot, Cardano should also be supported.
For more information: https://origintrail.io/technology
This proposer is in line with the challenge goals on the thinking that this will connect in another way Cardano to other blockchains for the solution of a common problem. However I am not sure if the Dapps, Products and  Integration is not better place for this proposal due to the obvious integration aspect of this proposal.
Dear proposer, I will strongly recommend to get in touch with the Challenge Team members and directly ask them if your proposal is for this challenge or not and then mention that you have done that. This will make all this guesswork unnecessary and your proposal graded higher.
I agree the answer covers some of the criteria and that this proposal effectively addresses the challenge.
f6_assessments.q1:
The proposer clearly states that he has developer experience but does not have experience with EVM or DKG. The proposer does not provide any plan for the proposal and that he is busy with another proposal and will try to outsource this one. This is very unsatisfactory as a plan explanation.
The proposer presents this funding as a bounty for someone else as a budget section of this proposal, there are no hours needed, professional experience needed or hourly rates presented.
The proposer has two proposals in fund 9 for a total ask of 15K.
There is no intention for further funding for this particular proposal from Catalyst. 
Unfortunately this proposal does not look very detailed and well developed.
I disagree that the project plans and budget supplied is feasible to deliver.
f6_assessments.q2:
The proposer states that this will be an open source contribution to DKG and this will be enough for the mitigation of the project. However the proposer does not provide any milestones and timeline for the community to be able to compare against the real progress of the project.
Success metrics are clear, no time line.
I disagree that this proposal provides me with sufficient information to assess the progress in attaining its stated goals.

f6_assessments.q0: The project was created to allow for cooperation between several chains via the DKG, which is intended to be compatible with many blockchains. However, I cannot visualize the project clearly from the information provided by the proposer. The proposer does not mention the purpose of the project, main activities, or potential audience, I tried to find the information in the proposal and the links provided by the proposer but failed because the proposer did not mention it at all. Besides, the proposer also does not provide technical information, or key indicators to evaluate the project. The content of risks is also not mentioned fully and reasonably, I regret not being able to see the seriousness of the proposer for this project.
f6_assessments.q1:
The proposed project is scheduled for implementation by the third-party partner (not the proposer) and is expected to be completed by October. $5000 in requested funds is used to outsource outsourcing. And the proposer does not mention any information about the work plan and budget allocation plan. It is difficult to understand how the project works and how the cash flow works when the proposer does not provide any other information. I suggest the proposer add more information to make the project clearer. Specifically, additional information on (1) work schedule, expected completion time, and work standards; (2) technical requirements, KPI numbers for specific tasks; (3) additional information about the budget will be paid to which individual/organization and for how many hours. All the above information is really necessary to have an objective view of the project.
The proposer does not provide any information about himself (including his full name). Proposer only refers can probably learn what is necessary for a month or two if really need it. And I noticed that the proposer omitted a lot of necessary information. This is not an exhaustive list of plans to evaluate this project and what it will bring to the Cardano ecosystem.
f6_assessments.q2: The success of the project is assessed by the proposer as would be an open-source contribution to DKG and Cardano officially added to the Origintrail website. However, the proposer does not show any key metrics, KPIs, traffic, or any expectations about this project in the future. Besides, the proposer also does not have a specific roadmap to implement the project, all the information provided is too general, not show the project clearly. I suggest that the proposer can supplement the information given above, as it is absolutely necessary for understanding the project and evaluating it objectively.

solution:
Implement a DKG backend on Cardano.
Cardano recently launched EVM on the test net, which should make this possible.
https://origintrail.io/technology
experience:
https://www.linkedin.com/in/martin-vavrovic-9617514a/ I’ve been a software developer for almost 10 years.
I have little experience with EVM or DKG, but will probably need this to implement the Ideation DAO I’m also proposing. I’ll have to learn this or hire someone.
